description:
Aspergillus caelatus is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It is known to be a member of the Aspergillus section Fumigati, which is a group of fungi commonly associated with human infections.

Aspergillus caelatus is characterized by its colonial morphology, which typically appears as velvety, green-colored colonies when grown on laboratory media. Microscopically, the fungus produces conidiophores (specialized reproductive structures) that bear the characteristic globose (spherical) vesicles, from which chains of conidia (asexual spores) radiate outward.

This species is considered an opportunistic pathogen, meaning it can cause infections in individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those with underlying medical conditions or those undergoing immunosuppressive treatments. Aspergillus caelatus has been associated with various forms of aspergillosis, a group of fungal infections caused by Aspergillus species.

Further research is still needed to fully understand the ecological niche, virulence factors, and clinical significance of Aspergillus caelatus in the context of human health and disease.
